title.narrative: MEDRC - regional support for water cooperation

description.narrative: The overall mission of MEDRC is to support the Middle East Peace Process through technical cooperation. As such the support to MEDRC should contribute to peace through technical cooperation at a government level on water resources so that conflict is prevented, and management and access to scarce water resources is improved. The technical cooperation is trilateral with activities including all core parties; Palestine, Israel and Jordan. While this can be considered as a relatively 'process-oriented' goal a number of more output oriented goals are identified in the result chain/theory of change, with a focus on bilateral activities in Palestine or Jordan with for example the development of PhD programmes for water specialists.

Projektet syftar till att stödja MEDRC, som är en del av den multilaterala fredsprocessen i Mellanöstern, till att främja samarbete och kunskapsutbyte kring vattenfrågor i MENA regionen.
MEDRC beräknas stödjas av Sida under en treårsperiod med 18,8 miljoner kronor.
The project aims to support MEDRC, which a part of the multilateral peace process in the Middle East, to promote cooperation and knowledge development on water issues in the MENA region

participating-org.narrative: MEDRC/The Middle East Desalination Research Center
University, college or other teaching institution, research institute or think-tank

sector.narrative: Water sector policy and administrative management

tag.narrative: 17.6 - Enhance North-South, South-South and triangular regional and international cooperation on and access to science, technology and innovation and enhance knowledge-sharing on mutually agreed terms, including through improved coordination among existing mechanisms, in particular at the United Nations level, and through a global technology facilitation mechanism.

17.6 - Stärka nord–syd-samarbetet, syd–syd-samarbetet och det regionala och internationella trepartssamarbetet kring och tillgången till vetenskap, teknik och innovation samt öka kunskapsutbytet på gemensamt överenskomna villkor, inklusive genom förbättrad samordning mellan befintliga mekanismer, i synnerhet på FN-nivå, och genom en global mekanism för teknikfrämjande.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The primary challenge in project implementation remains the political context, as anticipated at the outset of the project. The trilateral strategy specifically focuses on resilience and flexibility to ensure ongoing engagement when the external environment directly impacts programing. In 2019, this has been evidenced when unavoidable delays to the core party coordination meeting led to potential delays across the wider trilateral program. By engaging with each of the core parties bilaterally, MEDRC was able to convene additional meetings to ensure continuity in the program. Since 2017, all trilateral meetings have taken place in Europe. Whilst this provides an added dimension in terms of necessary visas, it has allowed meetings to take place which would not have been feasible had they been held in the region. MEDRC continues to work primarily with civil servants who hold the water and peace process files through these meetings. These activities provide regular structured contact between officials who often do not get an opportunity to meet without this forum thus explicitly linking it to the peace process. It is a long-term approach to supporting engagement between officials working on the Middle East Peace Process. MEDRC convened 4 meetings in 2019, 2 of which were funded by Sida, despite difficult political and security circumstances. MEDRC also convened its first trilateral study tour in 2019. The study tour was well received by all participants and was a good opportunity to consider new strategies for engagement in the trilateral program. MEDRC’s bilateral program in Palestine and Jordan has continued to be well received. At the start of 2019, MEDRC requested nominations from Palestine and Jordan with the caveat that all those nominated must attend and pass the five courses to make up the full award. Unfortunately, Palestinian colleagues were unable to join the course due to travel restrictions, however five Jordanians were able to complete the full set of courses. In future programming, MEDRC is considering a Gaza based course to overcome these issues around freedom of movement. Now into the second year, the rejuvenated student-led alumni forums have continued to be effective. MEDRC’s 10 funded PhD students have continued with their studies in Palestine and Jordan. The bilateral program is a vital part of MEDRC’s wider remit as it demonstrates that MEDRC is considered a credible partner for confidence building measures in the water sector.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
